was sent via    | Subscribe/Unsubscribe             ai+query@cs.cmu.edu
the AI-JOBS     | Available mailing lists include
mailing list.   |    AI-JOBS, LISP-JOBS, PROLOG-JOBS, AI-POSTDOC, AI-PREDOC
Received: from GLINDA.OZ.CS.CMU.EDU by A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU id aa22605;
          16 Mar 95 15:25:38 EST
Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 14:40:25 EST
From: Mark.Kantrowitz@GLINDA.OZ.CS.CMU.EDU
To: ai+ai-jobs@cs.cmu.edu, ai+ai-postdoc@cs.cmu.edu, ai+ai-predoc@cs.cmu.edu, 
    ai+lisp-jobs@cs.cmu.edu, ai+prolog-jobs@cs.cmu.edu
Subject: Admin: Results of mail/news survey.
Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU

I received 68 messages requesting that we retain the mailing lists and
not switch to a newsgroup. Also, nobody volunteered to administer the
newsgroup creation process. So we will be sticking with mailing lists.

I've appended a summary of the comments I received to this message.
In addition, I received mail from several people who found their
current job through the list, and from several employers who found an
employee through the list.

Several people also commented that they liked my Prime Time Freeware
for AI book/CD-ROM.

One person asked me to archive the messages somewhere in the AI
Repository's Web pages. This is already being done; I just
forgot to announce it to the list. All postings sent to the list are
automatically archived in appropriate subdirectories of
   ftp.cs.cmu.edu:/user/ai/jobs/
The equivalent web page is
   http://www.cs.cmu.edu:8001/Web/Groups/AI/html/other/jobs.html
Right now posts are given a filename based on the date and time received.

My decision is to remain with the status quo. If I ever decide to
create a newsgroup, it will be in addition to the mailing lists, and
will be moderated. There wouldn't be much additional effort on my part
(aside from the newsgroup creation bureaucracy), because posts to a
moderated newsgroup get sent to the moderator. 

Incidentally, I get some of the job announcements from newsgroups. I
wrote a PERL program that scans several newsgroups every night for
AI-related job postings, and saves them to a directory. About half of
them are junk, headhunters, or repeats, so I delete them, and the
remainder get posted about once a week. The rest of the announcements
are direct from the employers. It takes me only about 5 to 10 minutes a
week to manage the lists because of this automation, and most of that
time is spent dealing with bounces. 

Unfortunately, the scanner isn't sophisticated enough to detect
certain kinds of AI-related job announcements. For example, it cannot
retrieve AI Planning jobs, because the word "planning" is in about 75%
of all job postings (i.e., jobs that require employees with good
planning skills). 

Mark Kantrowitz
mkant@cs.cmu.edu


Here is a paraphrase of some of the comments I received:

   +  Can't read netnews. 

   +  Many employers do not permit employees to read newsgroups, but
      they do allow email.

   +  Employers who do permit netnews, do not always carry a full
      feed. Employees might feel very awkward asking them to carry the
      new newsgroup.

   +  Doesn't have the time to read news regularly.

   +  Mail messages are easier to redistribute.

   +  More likely to read messages via email.

   +  Mailing list has a high signal to noise ratio because it is
      effectively moderated.

   +  Mail is received quicker and in a more timely fashion than news.
      News posts are often delayed by days.

   +  News feed is unreliable, especially overseas.

   +  When actively searching for a job, mail is better.

   +  News expires and mail doesn't.

   +  Mail can be batch downloaded and read offline, keeping costs down.

   +  Can't use mail filtering tools with a newsgroup.

   +  The minimal effort in subscribing to a mailing list keeps riffraff out.

   +  Employer: Gets better and higher quality response from mailing list.

   +  Too much volume in news.

   +  If we switch to a newsgroup, it must be moderated. An unmoderated
      newsgroup would have more junk and noise than real announcements. 

   +  The volume of posts might not support three newsgroups, so may
      have just comp.ai.jobs.

   +  Call the newsgroup comp.ai.announce.jobs to prevent it from
      being used as a gripe forum.

   +  Permitting resumes is a bad idea -- it would increase the noise.

US-PA-Pittsburgh Machine Translation Language Developer (multiple), CMU

Target Language Technical Leader, Machine Translation Applications

The CATALYST project at the Center for Machine Translation, Carnegie
Mellon University, is seeking talented and energetic individuals for
the position of Target Language Technical Leader. We currently have
openings on four different target language applications: French,
German, Spanish, and Portuguese.

CATALYST is a large-scale MT application for commercial document
delivery in the domain of heavy machinery. Each Target Language
Technical Leader is responsible for the following tasks:

 * Work with project leaders to define workplan and schedule for
   target language module development, deployment and maintenance

 * Supervise and participate in the development and maintenance of each
   knowledge source for the application (lexicon, grammar,
   interpretation rules, etc.)

 * Integrate system knowledge sources into a run-time delivery module

 * Participate actively in requirements definition and QA

 * Maintain a responsive and professional relationship with customer
   personnel

Successful applicants must have the following qualifications:

 * Native or near-native fluency in at least one of these languages:
   French, German, Spanish or Portuguese

 * M.S. in Computer/Information Science (or related field),
   or equivalent experience

 * Strong programming skills in Lisp and Unix

 * Experience communicating and working productively within a
   development group

 * Experience in designing and implementing multi-module software systems

The following skills are also desirable:

 * Coursework in linguistics or computational linguistics

 * Experience in developing machine translation software or other
   types of language processing software

 * Experience with commercial software development and system
   engineering

 * Fluency in more than one of French, German, Spanish, Portuguese

 * Fluency in additional languages (Russian, Italian)

 * Some familiarity with PERL, C++

Full-time Salaried Position, Starting Range: $30,000 to $33,000 USD

Occasional Travel Required

Contact:        Eric Nyberg                             Phone: (412) 268-7281
                Center for Machine Translation          Fax:   (412) 268-6298

                Pittsburgh, PA 15213
                USA

Postscript form. Materials may also be submitted by fax, but EMail is
preferred.

From: grishman@cs.nyu.edu (Ralph Grishman)
Date: Thu Mar 16 16:52:57 EST 1995
Organization: New York University
Keywords: computational linguistics, job

The Proteus Project at New York University invites inquiries regarding
a full-time research position in computational linguistics for the
1995-96 year (starting September 1995 or before).  The Project is
involved in combining traditional, linguistically-based analysis
methods with statistically-based corpus methods to improve on the
state of the art in several areas of natural language processing,
including document retrieval (IR), information extraction, machine
translation, and language modeling for speech understanding.  We
currently have 5 full-time research staff pursuing research in all
these areas, with funding from ARPA, NSF, and the Linguistic Data
Consortium.

Applicants should have good programming skills (Lisp and C preferred),
a knowledge of statistical training methods, and experience in
applying computational linguistics techniques.  Applicants should have
a proven research record as demonstrated through publications.  An
M.S. is required; a Ph.D. is preferred.

Please send resume (including list of publications) to grishman@cs.nyu.edu
or by mail to
     Prof. Ralph Grishman
     Computer Science Department
     New York University
     715 Broadway, 7th Floor
     New York, NY 10003

          20 Mar 95 16:53:29 EST
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 16:52:10 EST
From: AI.Repository@GLINDA.OZ.CS.CMU.EDU
To: ai+ai-jobs@cs.cmu.edu
Subject: Job: NLP at SICS (Sweden)
Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU

From: ivan@sics.se (Ivan Bretan)
Subject: RESEARCH POSITION: Swedish Institute of Computer Science
Date: Fri Mar 17 07:57:19 EST 1995
Organization: Swedish Institute of Computer Science, Kista

The Swedish Institute of Computer Science (SICS) invites applications
for positions on its research staff for an initial period of 1--2 years
(with possibilities for extension) in the group for language
engineering and human-computer interaction. The successful candidates
will be expected to participate in existing research projects, perform
independent research and contribute to research contracts with
industrial and governmental sponsors.

The ideal candidates will have a Ph.D. degree in Computer Science,
Cognitive Science, Linguistics or a related discipline and will have
demonstrated strong potential for excellence in research. They will
have a solid background in language engineering and/or human-computer
interaction as well as experience in the development and implementation
of large systems (preferably using Prolog). People who like to work in
projects, and who like to take on responsibility for proposing and
driving their own research projects in areas relevant to the group, are
all encouraged to apply.

The research of the group focuses on user-adaptive interfaces,
multimodal communication, large-scale natural-language-processing
systems, application of statistical and machine-learning techniques to
natural-language processing, and text and document processing. Current
projects deal with user-adaptive help systems, speech-to-speech
translation, integration of natural-language and speech technology,
spoken-language interfaces to virtual realities, dialogue models for
voice-controlled telecom services, support systems for human
translation, and information filtering.

SICS is located just north of Stockholm and consists of over 50
professionals plus students and visitors. It is a non-profit research
foundation sponsored by the Swedish National Board for Technical and
Industrial Development and several major Swedish companies. In addition
to language engineering and human-computer interaction, SICS has a
strong position in distributed and parallel computer systems, logic
programming, high-speed networks, formal design methods, software
methodology, knowledge-based systems, neural networks and virtual
realities. SICS has close contacts with university- and institute-based
research both inside Sweden and in Europe, North America and Japan. More
information about SICS can be found at WWW site http://www.sics.se/.

Applications with CV and if possible addresses of two referees should
be sent (by mail, fax or e-mail) to the address below. SICS is firmly
committed to equal employment opportunity.

Information:

        Annika Waern or Mats Wiren
        Swedish Institute of Computer Science
        Box 1263
        S-164 28 Kista, Sweden

        E-mail: annika@sics.se, wiren@sics.se
        Phone:  +46 8 752 15 00
        Fax:    +46 8 751 72 30

          20 Mar 95 16:54:24 EST
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 16:52:45 EST
From: AI.Repository@GLINDA.OZ.CS.CMU.EDU
To: ai+ai-jobs@cs.cmu.edu
Subject: Job: Computational Linguistics at Univ. of Saarland (Saarbruecken)
Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU

From: Scott McGlashan <Scott.McGlashan@coli,uni-sb.de>
Date: Sun Mar 19 14:45:57 EST 1995
Organization: Universit des Saarlandes

                   UNIVERSITY OF THE SAARLAND

             DEPARTMENT OF COMPUTATIONAL LINGUISTICS

                     RESEARCH POSITIONS FOR
          COMPUTATIONAL LINGUISTS/COMPUTER SCIENTISTS


We are offering several research positions in the VERBMOBIL project.
This project involves many academic and industrial sites in Germany.
It is funded by the German Ministry for Research and Technology.
VERBMOBIL is concerned with the development of a portable translation
system in "face-to-face"-communication.

The VERBMOBIL-Subproject at the Department of Computational Linguistics
is concerned with Semantic Processing, in particular:

- the development of a semantic formalism
- the description of fragments of German  and Japanese in this formalism
- a computational treatment of anaphora and ellipsis
- implementing a working subsystem of VERBMOBIL

Candidates should have experience in computational linguistics or com-
puter science.  Experience in NL-Semantics, Logic, or AI/NL-
Programming is desirable. The successful candidates will be expected to
work both on theoretical issues and practical implementation.

The Department of Computational Linguistics and Speech Science has a well
-established international reputation in the study of NL grammar, NL se-
mantics and Speech. There is close cooperation with the German Center for
Artificial Intelligence (DFKI) and other institutions both inside and out-
side Germany.

The project started in 1993 and will last until December 1996, with the
possibility of extension depending on funding.  Successful candidates
would
be expected to take up their positions as soon as possible.  Positions
are on
the BAT IIa/Ib scale (from 65,000DM/year to 90,000/year).

Applications should include CV and an outline of research experience and
interests. Names and addresses of references would be helpful. Applica-
tions should be sent by mail, email or fax to the address below, from
where further information may also be obtained.

Applications should be sent as soon as possible, but no later than 21st
April 1995.


Prof. Dr. Manfred Pinkal
Dept. of Computational Linguistics
University of the Saarland
66041 Saarbruecken
Germany

email: sek-mp@coli.uni-sb.de
fax: +49 (681) 302-4351

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 10:47:34 GMT


JOB OPPORTUNITIES IN NATURAL LANGUAGE PROCESSING

Canon Research Centre Europe Ltd
Guildford, UK

Canon Research Centre Europe is looking for new recruits for its
Natural Language group. We are looking for people who will fit well
into the group on a permanent basis, rather than for a specific
project. A good computer science or linguistics background is
important, as are excellent programming skills. Top quality computer
scientists without any previous experience of Natural Language
Processing are encouraged to apply, as well as people with experience
in the area.

For more information about these openings, and about Canon Research
Centre Europe in general, our URL is http://www.cre.canon.co.uk/.

Our work ranges from long-term basic research to solving specific
problems quickly, and from interactive spoken dialogue systems to
large-scale text translation. We are currently embarking on embedding
our Natural Language software in realistic hardware platforms.
Skills/expertise relevant to this area would be useful.

Creativity and a flair for innovative work are essential.

Canon Research Centre Europe has been on the University of Surrey
Research Park since 1988. We doubt that you would be disappointed by
salary, equipment or working environment. Our recruitment policy is one
of equal opportunity.

Please note that you need to have the right to work in Britain. If you
are not a citizen of one of the member states of the European Union,
please check whether you are eligible before applying.

If you are interested, please mail a detailed CV to

        nljob@canon.co.uk

Plain text is preferred, but other formats (PostScript, LaTeX,
Framemaker, troff, etc.) are acceptable. Alternatively, you can send a
paper copy to:

        Kazuko Cooper (NL)
        Canon Research Centre Europe
        20 Alan Turing Road
        Surrey Research Park
        Guildford GU2 5YF, UK

        tel: +44-1483-448844
        fax: +44-1483-448845

There is no specific deadline for applications for these positions,
which will be processed as they arrive until suitable people have been
found. We expect to be hiring about 3 more people over the course of
1995.

If you need more information, please get in touch with Tom Wachtel
(wachtel@canon.co.uk).

--

Tom Wachtel (wachtel@canon.co.uk)

top organizations in the country, from small start-ups to Fortune 500

architectures and client-server based applications.

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU

                TENURE TRACK POSITION IN COMPUTER SCIENCE
            University of Maine Department of Computer Science

      QUALIFICATIONS:   A  Ph.D.  in  Computer  Science  or  a   related
      discipline  is required.    Candidates   should   have  a   strong
      interest     in    both  graduate/undergraduate    teaching    and
      scholarly   research.   Preference will  be  given  to  candidates
      with  a   primary  interest  in   Artificial  Intellligence,   but
      those   with   an interest  in  Language   Theory   and  Practice,
      Systems    (e.g.,   Operating  Systems,     Networking,    Machine
      Architecture), or Database System will also be considered.
           Candidates    are    expected  to  have  a   broad   computer
      science background,    and     to    complement    and     support
      both     the  graduate/undergraduate  curricula and  the  research
      activities   of  the  faculty.  Current areas of faculty  research
      interest include  algorithms and  complexity   theory,    software
      engineering   and  software  reuse, graphics,  numerical  methods,
      database   systems, and  operating   systems and  networking.   In
      addition,  major  projects  on campus   include    global  climate
      change and geographic information systems.

      RANK:   Appointment is expected to be at the Assistant   Professor
      level effective Sept. 1, 1995.

      RESPONSIBILITIES:    A  normal  course load  is  two  courses  per
      semester   in  computer  science   at   the  undergraduate  and/or
      graduate  levels.   In addition it is expected that a new  faculty
      member participate in department service activities and  establish
      a  research  program  that   includes   both   independent     and
      collaborative   research,    support    from    external   funding
      agencies,  and  involvement of   graduate/undergraduate   students
      through thesis and/or project work.

      COMPUTING    FACILITIES:    The  department  has   a   multivendor
      workstation/PC network,   including  SUN4s  under UNIX, SGIs,  IBM
      RTs   under  AIX,  and assorted  PCs and MACs in three   different
      laboratories.   This   network has   access  to   the   University
      mainframe   (IBM  3090) with    vector attachment, online  library
      system, and the Internet.

      SALARY     AND    BENEFITS:     Salary    and     benefits     are
      competitive.  Opportunities  exist  for  released time and  summer
      research  support.  Fringe benefits include health insurance, life
      insurance, and retirement (TIAA-CREF),  and  spouse or  dependents
      are eligible for a  50%  tuition waiver as  full-time students.

      DEPARTMENT:    The department has eight other members, and  offers
      BA,  BS and MS  degrees in Computer Science.

      CAMPUS   AND   COMMUNITY:   The University of Maine is  the   Land
      Grant   University  and  Sea Grant  College  of  Maine.  The  3200
      acre campus is located ten miles north  of  Bangor  in  the center
      of the state.  It is one  hour from the beautiful Bar Harbor  area
      and  the same  distance   to skiing  and  remote   hiking   areas.
      UM    has   a   student   population   of  approximately    11,001
      (including approximately 2300 graduate  students) and a faculty of
      690.

      TO APPLY:  Send a curriculum vitae and three letters of  reference
      to: Prof.  Thomas Byther, 5752 Neville Hall, University of  Maine,
      Orono,  ME 04469-5752.

      CLOSING:     Consideration    of  candidates will  begin  May  22,
      1995,  and will  continue  until  the position is filled.

      The   University  of  Maine is an  Equal   Opportunity/Affirmative
      Action Employer

Subject: AU-Brisbane CS and IS faculty positions at Griffith University
Organization: Griffith University, CIT.
Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 23:11:40 GMT


			(Repeat posting)

              GRIFFITH UNIVERSITY (Brisbane, Australia)

                Computing and Information Technology 

The School of Computing and Information Technology in the Faculty of
Science and Technology is a leading multi-disciplinary centre of teaching
and research in Information Technology.  It has 28 academic staff, over 
35 postgraduate research students, and about 500 undergraduate students. 
It offers a range of undergraduate degrees and postgraduate degrees 
spanning the spectrum of Computing and Information Technology.  It 
provides extensive computing facilities including networked laboratories 
of PCs, Unix servers and workstations, SGI Indy workstations, access to 
the QPSF's IBM SP2 parallel supercomputer on the campus, and connection to 
the Internet.  It hosts the Australian Software Quality Research Institute 
and is a participant in the CRC for Distributed Systems Technology.

The School now wishes to fill several vacant positions with outstanding
teachers and researchers.  The levels of the vacancies are listed
below.  Applications are invited from candidates with interests and
expertise in any area of:

    Information systems
    Software engineering
    Artificial intelligence
    Computer science (particularly computer graphics, distributed systems, 
		      and database systems)
	
Applicants should have qualifications and experience appropriate to the
level of the position being sought.

    Associate Professor - tenurable

    Senior Lecturer/Lecturer - tenurable
    Two positions

Information package: Ms Denise Vercoe, phone +61 7 875 5002, 
fax +61 7 875 5051, email D.Vercoe@cit.gu.edu.au.

Further information: Professor Rodney Topor, phone +61 7 875 5042, 
email R.Topor@cit.gu.edu.au.  

See also the Web page http://www.cit.gu.edu.au/.

Applications clearly indicating the level of position being sought,
and containing a recent publication, should be submitted to Mr James
Walden, Faculty Manager, Faculty of Science and Technology, Griffith
University, Queensland 4111, Australia.

Applications close on 31 March 1995

Salaries:
Associate Professor A$62,242 to A$68,571
Senior Lecturer A$51,692 to A$59,605
Lecturer A$42,198 to A$50,111

Notes for international applicants:
* Associate Professor <= (US) Full Professor
* Senior Lecturer ~= (US) Associate Professor
* Lecturer ~= (US) Assistant Professor
* Australian residents are preferred for the Associate Lecturer position
* A$1 ~= US$0.75
* Griffith University is a large modern university located in 
  Brisbane, a city of 1.2 million people with a subtropical climate 
  and plentiful professional, cultural, recreational and sporting
  opportunities.  Australia is a technological, cosmopolitan society
  that is mainly affluent, tolerant, liberal, secular, and crime-free.
  See http://www.csu.edu.au/education/australia.html for more details.

Griffith University is an equal opportunity employer.

Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU

COMPANY:  Carnegie Group, Inc.
POSITION:  Sr. Engineer ; Planning/Scheduling Algorithms R&D
LOCATION: Pittsburgh, PA

POSITION REQUIRES:
 * experience in innovative research and development of advanced
   algorithms in planning, scheduling, logistics, transportation.
 * experience as Principal Investigator or primary technical contributor in
   Government-funded R&D projects
 * Solid programming skills -- hands-on design and coding of functional
   research prototypes. 
 * Proposal-writing skills
 * PhD preferred
 * Publications highly desirable. 

RESPONSIBILITIES INCLUDE:

  This researcher will join an R&D team dedicated to creation and early
investigation of advanced technologies for Decision Support System
applications in Logistics Planning, Battlefield Planning, Medical Evacuation,
and related domains.

  The successful candidate will contribute to two current directions of
this R&D team:
    Primary responsibility -- research and development of innovative
approaches to reactive, dynamic planning and scheduling integrated with
command and control processes;
    Supporting responsibility -- development of novel Human-Machine interfaces
supporting decision-making process in highly dynamic, stressful environment. 

This would range from initial technology creation and investigation through
rapid prototyping of proof of concept demonstrations.  This researcher may
also support the transition of promising technologies into DSS development
efforts conducted by a separate team. Publications of technical papers and
preparation of powerful, innovative proposals for Government R&D funding
will also be part of her/his responsibilities.

 
Contact:  Pauline Nadeau, nadeau@cgi.com
          (412) 642-6900, 642-6906 (fax)

From: AI.Repository@GLINDA.OZ.CS.CMU.EDU
To: ai+ai-jobs@cs.cmu.edu
Subject: Job: Operations Scheduling at NASA/Ames (SF Bay, CA)
Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU

From: wedgingt@kronos.arc.nasa.gov (Will Edgington)
Reply-To: mus@ptolemy.arc.nasa.gov
Organization: NASA/ARC Computational Sciences Division
Date: Mon Mar 27 13:23:29 EST 1995

Position:      Research Programmer
Project:       Operations Scheduling

One position for a research programmer is available with the Operations
Scheduling project in the Computational Sciences Division at NASA Ames
Research Center. The research and development work of the Operations
Scheduling project is aimed at a problem of vital importance for the US
space program: dramatically reducing space mission operating costs
through the use of automation and Artificial Intelligence software
technology. The successful candidate will be joining a highly motivated
team in the development of software frameworks and algorithms and their
application to spacecraft sequencing problems, the automatic generation
of commands for autonomous space missions.

The successful candidate must satisfy the following requirements:

- American citizenship or permanent residency (this is a necessary
  condition for employment!);
- BS/MS (or experiential equivalent) in Computer Science or related
  fields;
- good working knowledge of Lisp, C and Unix;
- good written and verbal skills.

The following skills will be consider as definite advantages for
the successful candidate:

- familiarity with search techniques, constraint propagation, operations
  research, planning and scheduling;
- experience with the development of object-oriented systems;
- working knowledge of C++;
- experience with the development of user interfaces in Tcl/Tk.

Motivation to learn quickly about the previous topics is a definite
requirement.

The NASA Ames Research Center is located near Mountain View, in
northern California. The position offers a competitive compensation
package, excellent benefits, the opportunity to join a well-motivated,
hard-working team, and the chance to directly impact the future of the
US space program.

Applicants should send a resume to:

    Dr. Nicola Muscettola
    Mail Stop 269-2
    Recom Technologies / Information Sciences Division
    NASA Ames Research Center
    Moffett Field, CA  94035-1000

Email replies should be directed to 'mus@ptolemy.arc.nasa.gov'.

[Note: email replies to any other addresses may be delayed or lost.]

POSITIONS AVAILABLE FOR COMPUTATIONAL LINGUISTS

At least one position is available for computational linguists on a machine
translation project. The positions will be located either at Simon Fraser
University in Vancouver, British Columbia or at TCC Communications
Corporation in Victoria, British Columbia. In either case, the positions
will involve close interaction between the Natural Language Laboratory at
SFU and TCC. Tenure is for 1 year and is renewable subject to funding.
Salary is commensurate with experience.

Closing date for receipt of applications is April 18,1995

Applicants are sought with the following skills:

        * Knowledge of parsing and/or generation theory
        * Experience with machine translation technology
        * Experience with unification-based grammar formalisms
        * At least a Masters degree in linguistics or computing science
          is required
        * Native knowledge of Spanish an asset

Inquiries can be made to:

 Paul McFetridge
 mcfet@cs.sfu.ca

Applications with names and contact addresses of at least three people for
letters of reference should be sent to:

 Mr. John Grayson
 TCC Communications Corporation
 Box 2400, Sidney,

Case Base Architects

Inference is an international software and consulting services company
specializing in problem resolution technology.  Inference has pioneered the
use of a branch of Artificial Intelligence called Case Base Reasoning (CBR)
to improve the efficiency of corporate customer service centers.  This
technology is being marketed in our CBRX and Casepoint product lines which
are the market leaders in this technology.

We currently have openings for Case Base Architects who will work with our
clients to incorporate the CBR technology in their customer service systems. 


You will interact with the managers of the customer service centers,
interview problem solving experts,  design Case Base architectures, and
direct teams of customer service representatives in the development and
deployment of a problem solving case base.

Qualified candidates must be creative, articulate, personable,
self-confident and possess a broad base of talents and abilities including
presentation, writing, analytical, and client management skills.  Applicants 

should possess knowledge of leading technologies - Windows and UNIX, Oracle, 

Sybase, LAN/WAN.  Candidates must be willing to travel and work closely with 

with clients on site.

Inference provides an entreprenurial environment where you can make a real
difference on challenging, high visibility, projects. We offer extremely
competive salaries, an extensive benefits package, and room for growth.

Inference is an EOE/AA employer.

Please forward resume to: Jeanette Bergmann, Inference Corporation, 550 N.
Continental Blvd., El Segundo, Ca. 90036. Refer to posting CB130.

X-Vmsmail-To: @TEMP
Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU

COMPANY:  Carnegie Group, Inc.
POSITION:  Sr. Engineer ; Planning/Scheduling Algorithms R&D
LOCATION: Pittsburgh, PA

POSITION REQUIRES:
 * experience in innovative research and development of advanced
   algorithms in planning, scheduling, logistics, transportation.
 * experience as Principal Investigator or primary technical contributor in
   Government-funded R&D projects
 * Solid programming skills -- hands-on design and coding of functional
   research prototypes. 
 * Proposal-writing skills
 * PhD preferred
 * Publications highly desirable. 

RESPONSIBILITIES INCLUDE:

  This researcher will join an R&D team dedicated to creation and early
investigation of advanced technologies for Decision Support System
applications in Logistics Planning, Battlefield Planning, Medical Evacuation,
and related domains.

  The successful candidate will contribute to two current directions of
this R&D team:
    Primary responsibility -- research and development of innovative
approaches to reactive, dynamic planning and scheduling integrated with
command and control processes;
    Supporting responsibility -- development of novel Human-Machine interfaces
supporting decision-making process in highly dynamic, stressful environment. 

This would range from initial technology creation and investigation through
rapid prototyping of proof of concept demonstrations.  This researcher may
also support the transition of promising technologies into DSS development
efforts conducted by a separate team. Publications of technical papers and
preparation of powerful, innovative proposals for Government R&D funding
will also be part of her/his responsibilities.

 
Contact:  Pauline Nadeau, nadeau@cgi.com
          (412) 642-6900, 642-6906 (fax)

I am in dire need of someone who can put together a solid and effective
index for a somewhat advanced book on Fuzzy Logic. I am submitting a bid
to package a job, and am including about $1300 for an indexer (may be
negotiable). The best situation would be if I could find someone who had
both experience indexing and knows something about Fuzzy Logic, rather
than just someone who would be able to submit a key-word list. 

The book will about 600 pages, and the job will need to be done fairly
quickly (like 7-to-10 day turn-around), to probably go out around the last
week of April.

If anyone knows someone who can help me and might be interested, please
have them send me e-mail that includes their name, phone number, address,
and some idea of their experience in both in indexing and in computer
language and terminology.

Thanks in advance for any help.

-- 
Reuben
kant@denali.ccs.neu.edu

Subject: US-PA-PITTSBURGH-C++/AI/DBMS Carnegie Mellon University
Date: 31 Mar 1995 21:00:34 GMT
Organization: Carnegie Mellon University

*******************************************************************************
RESEARCH PROGRAMMERS
ROBOTICS INSTITUTE
CARNEGIE MELLON UNIVERSITY
 
POSITION : Research Programmers
*******************************************************************************
 
DESCRIPTION:
Research Programmers (2-4) needed for a project involving
development of Intelligent Agents for information access, decision support
and interoperability in the HealthCare domain. The project will involve
working on integrating information sources with different
architectures, developing agents and protocols to access information
across architectures. The research content of the project will be
significant but the project also provides an opportunity to work
with diverse architectures both hardware (Apple, PC compatibles and
UNIX workstations) and software (ORACLE, UNIX, TCP/IP, SNA, TCL/TK).
The task is challenging in that it involves developing state of the
art Intelligent Distributed Systems / Intelligent Agents in a real world
environment while supporting research in machine learning, case-based
reasoning and distributed systems.
 
The work environment is supportive and informal. The task involves
interacting with faculty, graduate students and research programmers
in a high motivation and high technical competency environment.
Publishing of technical papers based on contributed ideas is
encouraged. Compensation will be based on experience and
qualifications.
 
The project is in start up phase, so suitable candidates must be able to
start immediately.
 
The suitable candidates are expected to meet the following
requirements.
 
QUALIFICATIONS :
 
REQUIRED
Strong C/C++ skills.
BS Degree in CS / related field.
Ability to get up to speed on new software
Ability to meet deadlines, work in a research environments
Ability to work independently with minimal supervision
 
Good oral and written communication skills
Familiarity with AI techniques
Good inter-personal skills
 
DESIRED
Experience in databases and SQL / ORACLE
Experience with writing distributed (network) software
Experience with software security issues
Familiarity with LISP/Prolog
Familiarity with current software engineering techniques and practices
 
TO APPLY :
Send your resume (preferably by e-mail) to either
 
Prof. Katia Sycara
(katia+@cs.cmu.edu)
3315 Doherty Hall
Robotics Institute
Carnegie Mellon University
5000 Forbes Ave.
Pittsburgh PA 15213
 or
 
Anandeep Pannu

3300B Doherty Hall
Robotics Institute

	id AA05343; Tue, 4 Apr 95 18:56:17 PDT

	id AA17625; Tue, 4 Apr 1995 18:53:06 -0700
Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 18:53:06 -0700
From: Steve Chien <chien@aig.jpl.nasa.gov>
Message-Id: <9504050153.AA17625@keynes>
To: ai+ai-jobs@CS.CMU.EDU
Subject: Job:  JPL/Caltech: AI, Planning, Scheduling, Monitoring (Pasadena, CA)
X-Sun-Charset: US-ASCII
Content-Length: 4410
Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU

Employment Opportunity for recent and upcoming graduates:

     The Artificial Intelligence (AI) Group at the Jet Propulsion
Laboratory (JPL), California Institute of Technology is seeking
candidates at the BA/BS and MA/MS level to work in the Planning and
Scheduling subgroup and Model-based Reasoning subgroups.  Openings are
permanent full-time positions.  Contact information is lited below.

Planning and Scheduling:

   A candidate must hold a degree in Computer Science, Electrical
Engineering or related area, and must possess programming skills in C
and/or LISP, as well has have some experience with the UNIX environment.

   Ideally, a candidate would also have some background in one or more
of the following areas: artificial intelligence, statistics,
operations research, or image processing.

   The AI Group conducts research and develops applications in the
form of deliverable software packages that are put to use by
scientists or NASA operations personnel. The planning and scheduling
subgroup focusses on applications of planning to automated image
processing and generation of antenna operations procedures as well as
scheduling and resource allocation problems of interest to NASA.  This
work involves extending the state-of-the-art in planning and
scheduling as well as applications to real-world problems.  The
primary responsibilities for the opening are software development and
algorithm design.

  Other ongoing efforts in the AI Group involve: intelligent systems
monitoring, model-based reasoning, machine learning, and pattern
recognition/image understanding.

If you are interested in this position, please send a resume and any
other supporting materials to the address below (electronic submission
of resumes encouraged).  Please include an e-mail address and phone
number at which you can be reached.  Recent graduates and students
graduating May 1995 are strongly encouraged to apply.  Please include
information on your citizenship status with your application.

            Dr. Steve A. Chien
            Technical Group Leader,
            Artificial Intelligence Group
            Jet Propulsion Laboratory, MS 525-3660
            California Institute of Technology
            Pasadena, California 91109-8099

Send email submissions to:  job1@aig.jpl.nasa.gov


Model-based Reasoning:


  A candidate for permanent employment must hold a degree in Computer Science,
Electrical Engineering or a related area, and must possess programming skills
in C and/or LISP, as well as have some experience with UNIX/X11 environments.

  Ideally, a candidate would also have some background in one or more of
the following areas: artificial intelligence, monitoring/diagnosis,
time-series analysis/visualization, applied statistics, model-based
reasoning, machine learning (clustering).

  The AI Group conducts research and develops applications in the form of
deliverable software packages that are put to use by scientists or NASA
operations personnel.  The model-based reasoning subgroup focusses on
acquiring and using causal/qualitative and statistical models to automate
monitoring and diagnosis tasks for problems of interest to NASA.  The
subgroup's current projects involve both ground and onboard operations for
a wide-variety of application domains: the Space Shuttle, Earth-orbiting
satellites, and small unmanned deep-space spacecraft.

  Our work involves extending the state-of-the-art in model-based reasoning
to real-world problems.  The primary responsibilities for these openings
are software development and algorithm design.

  Other ongoing efforts in the AI Group include: planning/scheduling
and pattern recognition/image understanding.

  If you are interested in these positions, please send a resume and any
other supporting materials to the address below (electronic submission
of resumes is encouraged).  Please include an e-mail address and phone
number at which you can be reached.  Recent graduates and students
graduating in May of 1995 are strongly encouraged to apply.  Please
indicate your citizenship status with your application.

            Dr. Dennis DeCoste,
            Technical Group Leader,
            Artificial Intelligence Group
            Jet Propulsion Laboratory, MS 525-3660
            California Institute of Technology
            Pasadena, California 91109-8099

Please send email submissions to:  job2@aig.jpl.nasa.gov

From: mdonelan@osf1.gmu.edu (Mark H Donelan)
Subject: US,Wash DC, Neural Net, VR, R&D
Date: 3 Apr 1995 03:06:31 GMT
Organization: George Mason University, Fairfax, Virginia, USA

Please do not reply to this email address since it is not a 
commercial account.  Snail mail and FAX are at bottom of posting.

Aviation Technology Systems, a leading edge developer of real time systems
is currently seeking team-oriented, dedicated, Software Engineers with
the following expertise for immediate openings in our Crystal City, VA
office (near Washington D.C.):

Neural Networks/Virtual Reality
Traffic Management

NN/VR
Two positions for creative individuals in an R&D environment.  Both positions
require a strong mathematical background, solid algorithmic development
skills, and systems design experience.  One position requires theoretical
and applied AI, Neural Network (MATLAB a plus), Optimization (dynamic
programming), Pattern Recognition, and Fuzzy Logic experience.  The graphics
position requires a background in 2D graphics (map projections), Virtual
Reality, 3D rendering, and real-time animation (a mathematical understanding
of graphics and rendering is preferred); X-Windows and Xlib experience.
Successful candidates must possess C/C++, Windows or OS/2, UNIX, Motif
skills, a BS in C.S, E.E., Math or Physics and 5+ years related experience
or 3+ years relevant experience and a Master's in C.S., E.E., Math or Physics
with a concentration in AI, Neural Networks, 3D Graphics or Virtual Reality
(graphics position).

Traffic Management
One hands on technical task lead and one software engineer to perform
modifications, maintenance, enhancements, and new system development for
large, client/server application.  Minimum 5 years C/UNIX programming
experience plus direct experience in at least 2 of the following areas:
optimization (dynamic programming), client/server applications, non-package
low-level database design and development, and weather depiction graphics.
Lead presents demonstrations, leads small team, and must possess leadership
experience with large client/server applications.  Rotating beeper support
required.  Preferred qualifications: C++ programming experience, master's
degree in C.S., E.E., Math or Physics.

ALL CANDIDATES MUST MEET ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR ACCESS TO CLASSIFIED
INFORMATION.

ATS offers a challenging work environment and a comprehensive benefits
package.  For immediate consideration, mail or fax your resume, indicating
position of interest to:
				ATS
				P.O. Box 3364
				Attn: INET4/2
				Manassas, VA  22110
				FAX 703.330.0043
No phone calls please.
An Equal Opportunity Employer. M/F/D/V.
Please do not reply to the email address on this posting since it
is not a commercial address.

Subject: Job: Speech Recognition (London)
Date: Fri, 07 Apr 95 12:57:55 -0400
Message-ID: <17893.797273875@GLINDA.OZ.CS.CMU.EDU>
From: Mark Kantrowitz <AI_Repository@GLINDA.OZ.CS.CMU.EDU>
Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU


From: Lesley Matheson <lrm@CS.Princeton.EDU>
Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 10:48:30 -0500

			Signal Analysis Specialist
			Programmer, Systems Designer

The HAL Trust is a research and development project funded to implement
a speech recognition system that incorporates a cognitive-based-phonological
strategy.  The project has implemented the cognitive strategy and produced 
encouraging results.  The approach seems to yield a highly efficient and
effective back end to a recognition system.

We are currently seeking to obtain greater expertise in the fields of signal 
processing, programming and computational science.  We anticipate hiring at 
least one full-time researcher-developer.  The near term objective is to 
expand and complete the development of a full pilot system.  To accomplish 
this we seek the expertise required for the development of traditional front
ends to recognition systems, such as knowledge of (acoustic) signal processing 
techniques.  In particular we seek a strong creative ability to tailor front 
end development to the pattern requirements of the cognitive-based strategies.
We are open to exploration of traditional methodologies such as hidden Markov 
models but would also value ideas on alternative approaches.  Programming 
skills and computational sophistication are highly desirable.
	
We envision an intense research and development effort over the next 6-12 
months.  The position would provide the opportunity to make a significant 
research contribution to the overall design of the system.  In addition, the
objective of the project is to develop a commercial project.  The trust has 
significant managerial expertise involved in
the project.  This creates an opportunity for growth and long
term involvement for a suitably qualified individual.

At present the project is based at the University of London.  The position
is for an initial period of 6-12 months at the University facilities with the
potential for a longer term commitment at the end of one year.  The position
is available immediately.  Salary is commensurate with expertise and the cost 
of living in London.  For further information please contact:


		Professor Jonathan Kaye
		or Geoff Williams
		Department of Linguistics
		SOAS, University of London
		Thornhaugh St.
		London, UK WC1H OXG
		JK@soas.ac.uk or
		GW@soas.ac.uk
		+44-71-323-6362 (tel. and fax)

			or

		Dr. Lesley Matheson
		NEC Research Institute
		4 Independence Way
		Princeton, NJ 08540
		609-951-2739
		lrm@princeton.edu

Technical Solutions, Inc. has an immediate opening for the following regular
full time position in New York:

   Project Engineer: REF# IP-PAPH630-LS22: NY

POSITION DESCRIPTION: Project Engineer for design and applications in speech
coding, speech recognition, and speech synthesis.  Domestic and overseas
travel required.

	- BSEE.
	- 2+ years in micro-processor based electronics systems design.
	- 5+ years experience in digital/analog circuit design.
	- Experience in Assembly language programming.
	- DSP experience a  plus.

ment departments.  Candidates for any position must have a minimum of 2 
years post graduation industry experience.

dates already authorized to work in the USA need apply.

Subject: Job: HCI & Intel. Agents at Oregon Graduate Institute
Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU

From: pcohen@church (Phil Cohen)
Subject: WANTED IMMEDIATELY: Multitalented Research Programmers
Date: 05 Apr 1995 18:57:09 GMT
Organization: Oregon Graduate Institute - Computer Science & Engineering


WANTED IMMEDIATELY!    Multitalented Research Programmers

Center for Human-Computer Communication
Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering
Oregon Graduate Institute of Science and Technology


The Center for Human-Computer Communication (CHCC) is looking for
unique individuals who want to advance the state of the art in
multimodal user interfaces and intelligent agent architectures. The
ideal candidate should be fluent in a variety of systems,
architectures and programming languages, understand user interface
tools, especially some of the new modalities of communication (speech,
gesture, handwriting) and most of all, be committed to making a strong
contribution to the next generation of user interfaces and intelligent
systems.  Specifically, you should have the following:

EDUCATION: MS Computer Science with substantial work experience (PhD
ok too!)  Experience with speech recognition, gesture recognition,
handwriting recognition, and/or natural language processing required.
Knowledge of HMMs and neural nets is higly desirable. 
Experience with geographic mapping systems, logic programming, distributed
databases, and networking would also be desirable.  Finally, knowledge
of CORBA would  be a big plus.
  
SKILLS: PC's: 	MS Windows and Visual Basic,  OLE,  Prolog, C, C++
	 Unix:  X-Windows, C, C++, Prolog, shell and Perl scripts, WCL,
		Tcl and Tk
 		
TASK: You will be responsible for building next generation multimodal
interfaces, implemented in an intelligent agent architecture.  Users
will state their needs through a multimodal interface integrating
speech recognition, natural language processing, handwriting,
gestures, and direct manipulation.  You will build an architecture
allowing each modality to be used whenever  appropriate and to supply
constraints to the others.   The design of the interface will be guided
by ongoing usability experiments, whose systems you will also support.

The interface will be be part of an intelligent agent architecture,
which allows distributed information resources operating on multiple
platforms to communicate and cooperate over the Internet in addressing
users' needs.  The architecture will span multiple platforms (PC's,
Unix, Macs, PDA's) and network bandwidths. To maximize generality, it
will take advantage of emerging standards such as CORBA.

Salary and benefits will be competitive.
        
INSTITUTION: The Center for Human-Computer Communication is a newly formed 
research center at OGI within the Department of Computer Science and 
Engineering.   We are a multidisciplinary group, including computer 
scientists, psychologists, and linguists dedicated to advancing the science 
and technology of human-computer and human-human communication. Research 
support comes from ARPA, NSF, NASA, the State of Oregon, and a variety of 
computer and telecommunications companies. A new usability and intelligent 
systems laboratory includes Sun sparcstations, PC's, PowerMacs, and PDA's, 
as well as state-of-the-art video recording and production equipment. 

The Department of Computer Science and Engineering is one of the most 
rapidly growing departments in the U.S., with 20 full-time professors, over 
100 Ph.D. and M.S. students, and a departmental research budget exceeding 
$6M per year.  CSE's research is organized around a number of 
Centers, including CHCC, the Center for Spoken Language Understanding, and 
the Data Intensive Systems Center. In these areas of specialization, CSE is 
the leading computer science department on the West Coast.

The Oregon Graduate Institute of Science and Technology is located 12 miles 
west of Portland, Oregon, and serves the high-technology educational needs 
of Intel, Tektronix, Mentor Graphics, and other local corporations. The 
Portland Metro area has a rapidly growing population (> 1.2M people), but 
is still the most affordable major city on the West Coast. The city offers 
the full range of cultural, culinary, and athletic opportunities to be 
expected from a cosmopolitan center.   For the outdoors enthusiast, excellent 
skiing, windsurfing, sailing, hiking, beachcombing, etc. are within an 
hour's drive. 

Further information about CSE and OGI can be found on the web at:
http::www.cse.ogi.edu

Please reply with a resume, statement of interests and availability, as 
well as names of three references  to:

Phil Cohen   (pcohen@cse.ogi.edu)  (503)690-1326
Professor and Director
Center for Human-Computer Communication
Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering
Oregon Graduate Institute of Science and Technology
P.O. Box 91000
Portland, OR 97034

AI Job Offered
---------------

Mitel Corporation is looking for a highly motivated individual to join
a team which will create a next generation service creation
environment.  The environment will combine existing telecom and data
communications using PC and ATM technology. The responsibilities of the
position include the design, implementation and testing of a PC-based
communication system prototype.

machine learning, knowledge based systems, explanation and justification.

Smalltalk, Microsoft Chicago and NTAS experience an asset.

Position Available in Robotics and Automation Software Development


We are seeking a software-oriented professional to work on the design and
development of software systems for industrial robotics and automation.

The position will include work in the following areas:

        o "Task-level" programming systems for robotics and motion control.

        o "Task-level" interfaces to machine vision and other sensors.

        o Coordination of multiple automation systems.

        o Graphical user interfaces.

        o Network interfaces.

        o Robot language development

        o Real-time operating systems.


Qualifications:

        A Master of Science or Doctorate Degree in Engineering, Computer
        Science, or a related field.

        The applicants must be excellent computer programmers with
        substantial programming experience.

        Course work or experience in robotics, machine control,
        mathematics, language design, user interface design, computer
        networks, and computer vision.

        Experience with real-time operating systems is desirable.

        Available by August 1995.

Job environment:

        This position is with a small group of software engineers in
        Southern California, part of a 250+ employee company which designs
        and manufactures industrial robots, machine vision systems, and
        motion controllers.  The company has been on the cutting edge of
        these areas for over 10 years.  The working environment is a small
        office of casual, but hard-working individuals, in a suburban
        setting.

                Clifford C. Geschke, Ph.D.

                Adept Technology Inc.
                17800 Castleton Street,  Suite 175
                City of Industry,  CA  91748

        Position Available in Computer Vision Software Development

We are seeking a software-oriented professional to work on the
design and development of industrial vision systems.  The projects
will include work in the following areas:

        o Model-based object recognition.

        o High-speed, high accuracy 2-D measurement, inspection, and
          robot guidance.

        o General image processing operations (convolutions, etc.)

        o Normalized correlation.

        o Character verification and recognition.

        o Operator interfaces using windows and graphics.

        o Specification-level design of dedicated vision hardware.

        o 2-D and 3-D calibration.

        o Possibly color and 3-D vision.

Qualifications:

        An M.S. or Ph.D. in Electrical and Computer Engineering,
        Computer Science, or a related field, with a STRONG EMPHASIS on
        computer vision and software design.

        Course work or experience in computer vision, computer science,
        mathematics, and preferably robotics.

        Experience with high level programming languages such as C
        required and exposure to assembly languages and UNIX
        desirable.

        Available IMMEDIATELY, if possible, but no later than September 1995.

Job environment:

        The position is with a small group of software engineers in southern
        California, part of a 250+ employee company with high-technology
        products in object recognition, visual inspection, robotic assembly,
        and machine control.  We have been on the cutting edge of these areas
        for over 10 years.  The working environment is a small office
        of casual, but hard-working individuals, in a suburban setting.

Subject: US/TX/SAN ANTONIO/TRAINING SYS PROJ LEADER/
Organization: Online Career Center
Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 13:13:50 GMT


Training Systems and Simulators Project Leader
Position Code: 09504
 
Supervise activities of Instructional Systems Development (ISD)
teams in the design, development, and production of interactive
multimedia programs, performance support systems, and desktop
simulations. Lead project teams to conduct research in emerging
learning and instructional design theories. Promote efforts in
instructional systems, including proposal development. Manage
ISD/multimedia projects, number of hours of interactive
courseware produced on individual projects ranges from 40-100.
Work with advanced training technologies, such as Virtual
Environment (VE), speech recognition systems, computer-generated
imagery (CGI), and digital video. Determine customer training
needs and recommend appropriate instructional strategies,
methods, media. Interpret solicitations, develop technical and
cost proposals, and negotiate contracts. Assist with staff
development, program budgeting and scheduling, product quality
control, contract administration, and client interface. Requires
a MA or PhD, in instructional systems and a minimum of 15 years
experience in ISD project management and 10 years experience in
CBT/IVD/DVI design and production. Must have a successful track
record in marketing (ISD) instructional systems design and
interactive multimedia production. Should be familiar with ICW
authoring systems, such as Visual Basic, Authorware Professional;
electronic performance support systems; distance learning
technologies, Information Mapping; Hypermedia; intelligent
tutoring systems; and desktop simulation. Must be able to
interact with customers and co-workers. Must be a US citizen and
be eligible to obtain a DOD security clearance. 
 
Southwest Research Institute, founded in 1947 in San Antonio,
Texas, is an independent, applied engineering and physical
sciences R&D organization. Total revenue for 1994 was 243 million
dollars. Currently 60% to 65% of our work is performed for
private industrial sponsors with the balance
derived from research for various government agencies. 
 
The addition of staff members of high competence is essential to
the company's success. Since technical ability is what the
Institute has to offer, we look for people who measure success
according to their contributions to the advancement of their
chosen field of technology. The opportunities for technical and
professional growth are excellent at the Institute because of the
availability of a wide variety of challenging technical
assignments, and the fact that employees are evaluated on the
basis of their performance in handling such assignmets. Our
company offers competitive salaries and a comprehensive benefits
package. 
 
San Antonio, the 9th largest city in the country with a
population of 935,933, has a cost of living rated as one of the
lowest among large U.S. cities.  
 
Forward resumes to:(Be sure to indicate Position Code of
interest)
 
Via Mail: Professional Staffing, Southwest Research Institute,
P.O. Drawer 28510, San Antonio, Texas, 78228-0510
 
Via Fax: (210) 522-3990, Attention Professional Staffing Dept.
 
Via Email: personnel@swri.org
 
Southwest Research Institute is an Affirmative Action/Equal
Opportunity Employer.

invites applications for several full-time positions at the Master's and
Ph.D. levels, in areas such as:

 * Intelligent Agents
 * Human-Computer Interfaces

Science. USC/ISI is a leading research laboratory with over 200 staff members

COMPUTER VISION AT MICROSOFT RESEARCH

We are looking for candidates for a position in computer vision
research at Microsoft Research.  The main area of interest is in
vision-based human-computer interaction, or "looking at people" -- for
example, tracking people or recognizing gestures.  The ideal candidate
will have a Ph.D. in computer science or a related field, a strong
research background in computer vision, experience in building vision
systems, and specific experience with applying vision technology to HCI.

Microsoft Research is part of Microsoft's Advanced Technology Division.
 There are currently about 75 researchers in areas such as operating
systems, speech, natural language, decision theory, program analysis,
computer graphics and user interfaces.  The Research groups maintain
close ties to other parts of the company (e.g. product development and
consumer applications).  We're located in Redmond, Washington (near Seattle).

For details about applying, see the official announcement on
Microsoft's Web page:  http://www.microsoft.com.  (Look for the job
posting under Employment Opportunities/Advanced Technology/Development
and Research.)  If you don't have WWW access, call the Microsoft job
line at 1-800-892-3181 or 1-206-936-5500.  For further questions,
e-mail jobinfo@microsoft.com.

Subject: Job: Speech and NLP at BBN
Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU

From: scolbath@bbn.com (Sean Colbath)
Subject: JOB:  Speech and Natural Language jobs at BBN
Date: 4 Apr 1995 21:32:44 GMT
Organization: Bolt, Beranek & Newman, Inc.

My company, BBN, is looking to hire a developer to help build speech- and
natural-language-related applications.  BBN is currently one of the leaders
in speech recognition and natural language processing, in both the research
and commercial arenas.  If you'd be interested doing something like this,
please send your responses to Terri Simon-Barron (tsimon@bbn.com).  Email
is acceptable, or US mail them to Terri at BBN, 10 Moulton St., Cambridge,
MA 02138.


=========================================================================

POSITION TITLE:    Speech Applications Engineer (SAE)

POSITION DESCRIPTION: (ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS)

The SAE will develop prototypes of new applications using the advanced
speech recognition technology developed at BBN.  These applications
will serve the needs of the government, commercial, and education
worlds.  You will work within a department of roughly 45 technical
staff who develop advanced speech recognition and understanding
technology.  The resources include over 100 unix hosts and more than
175 GB of disk, distributed over 24 ethernets.  The position requires
broad skills in software development and interfaces.

Specific responsibilities include:
 - learn about the capabilities and interfaces for our speech
        recognition systems.
 - rapid prototyping of applications, including human interfaces.
 - test the prototypes on small numbers of potential users
 - modification of prototypes as needed.
 - demonstrate prototype applications within and outside BBN.


EDUCATION REQUIRED:    Bachelor's degree in computer science or related field.

EXPERIENCE/SPECIAL SKILLS REQUIRED:

A minimum of 3 years of C software development under UNIX OS within a
larger group.  Strong problem solving skills and the ability to work within
a group are required.  Good programming skills are required (C, C++, Lisp,
GUI programming) for tool building.  Willingness to apply for DoD clearance
is a plus.  Strong verbal communication and presentation skills highly
desirable.  US citizenship also highly desirable.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------The Speech and Language Processing Department of BBN Systems and
Technologies, a subsidiary of Bolt Beranek and Newman Inc. (NYSE:BBN),
has been a world leader in computer-based speech and language research
and development for about 25 years.  The department continues to make
cutting-edge advances in the areas of large-vocabulary
speaker-independent continuous speech recognition, keyword and topic
spotting, speaker identification, language identification, natural
language understanding, interactive spoken language systems,
information retrieval, data extraction from text, and handwriting
recognition.  These technologies are integrated with other BBN
capabilities in the areas of communications, graphics, and human
factors to develop systems that enhance the human-machine interface.
For its fiscal year ended June 30, 1994, BBN had revenue of $196
million.

Statistician/Expert Systems Programmer

JOB BACKGROUND

Transamerica is developing Expert Systems for use in the appraisal industry.
This new industry has been termed Automated Valuation Systems (AVS) and is  
an emerging real world industry that already has several players.

QUALIFICATIONS

in addition to C/C++ and Pascal.

The applicant must have an excellent background in statistics and rule/expert
system based modeling. The applicant will be applying any and all of the above
modeling systems to develop software that will accurately predict the value of
homes. We are looking for the person who
  
  o Is self motivated and directed.
  o Enjoys their work and is unobstructed by the "clock". 
  o Works well as a team member or on their own.
  o Understands the importance of schedules and timeliness.
  o Wants to make a contribution.
  o Wants to have his/her ideas make a difference.

From: violetta+@NL.CS.CMU.EDU (Violetta Cavalli-Sforza)
Subject: US-PA-Pittsburgh Machine Translation Language Developer (Italian), CMU
Date: 4 Apr 1995 19:21:03 GMT
Organization: Carnegie-Mellon University, School of Computer Science

US-PA-Pittsburgh Machine Translation Language Developer (Italian), CMU

Research Assistant, Machine Translation Applications

The CATALYST Project at Center for Machine Translation, Carnegie Mellon
University, is seeking a full-time staff member to work on the Italian
generation component of a large-scale machine translation system.  The
system is targeted at the production of commercial documents in the domain
of heavy machinery.  The chosen applicant will participate in the creation
and testing of Italian computational lexicon entries, grammar rules, and
semantic mapping rules.

Required skills:
  * Native fluency in Italian.
  * Programming experience (especially in Lisp, Unix tools).
  * Desire to learn about computational linguistics.

Preferred skills:
  * Experience with computational grammars, computational lexicons, or
    similar.
  * Experience with machine translation.
  * Formal training in computational linguistics.

Starting salary range is $23,000 - 30,000.  Actual salary offered will
depend on experience and skills.  The position requires a committment
of approximately 2 years, with the possibility of an extension.

To apply, please send your resume to Violetta Cavalli-Sforza, whom you
may also contact via electronic mail or FAX for further information.

  Violetta Cavalli-Sforza
  Center for Machine Translation
  Carnegie Mellon University
  5000 Forbes Avenue
  Pittsburgh, PA 15213

  email: violetta@cs.cmu.edu
  Fax:  (412) 268-6298

The Center for Machine Translation (CMT) is a research center within
the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University. Founded
in 1986, the CMT presently includes about 50 faculty, staff, graduate
students, and visiting researchers. The CMT conducts basic and applied
research in Machine Translation, Natural Language Processing, text
extraction, and computer-aided language instruction.

Pittsburgh is a friendly, medium-sized city in the western part of
Pennsylvania.  It offers a relatively rich cultural environment and low
cost of living and is not too distant from major midwestern and east
coast cities.

Subject: Job: Expert Systems at Unisys (Madison, WI)
Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU

From: armagan@gvls1.vfl.paramax.com (Armagan Ozdinc)
Subject: Expert Systems in Health Care - Madison, WI
Organization: Unisys Corporation, Paoli, PA
Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 21:02:51 GMT



BACKGROUND:

Unisys Corporation - Health Information Management has recently won 
a contract from the State of Wisconsin to develop an expert system which
will intelligently analyze the historical Medicaid claims data to identify
and present potential problems associated with different aspects of Medicaid
utilization.  The primary application target is the detection of fraud and
abuse in selected Medicaid service areas.

Our expert system, called Knowledge-Based Utilization Management Assistant
(KUMA), will operate in a client-server mode on a network of PCs and HP9000.
All user interaction with the KUMA system will be through a Graphical User
Interface (GUI) executing on the client PCs.  KUMA Knowledge Server will be
running on the HP platform and accessing ORACLE data bases stored on the
same platform.  KUMA will be implemented using Nexpert Object, a commercial
expert system shell, and Visual Basic.

KUMA is currently under development at the Valley Forge Engineering Center
of Unisys Corporation in Paoli, Pennsylvania, outside Philadelphia.  The
project follows a rapid-prototyping model with new demonstrations scheduled
in Madison, Wisconsin for approximately every five  months.


JOB DESCRIPTION:

We are currently looking for an energetic software engineer as a liaison
person between the development team in Paoli, Pennsylvania and the
customer (State of Wisconsin).  

Location:  
---------
Unisys office in Madison, Wisconsin.



Duties:
-------
- Configuring and maintaining the KUMA operation environment.

- Testing and validating components of KUMA before each demonstration and
  the final release.

- Installing KUMA releases.

- Interacting with the customer to get their feedback about KUMA and 
  providing the developers with the feedback.

- Assisting in development and maintenance of knowledge bases.

- Assisting in preparation of documentation for end users.


Requirements:
-------------
- At least B.S. in Computer Science or a related field.

- At least 2 years of working experience in expert system development, 
  testing, and maintenance.

- Strong background in GUI, object-oriented programming, data modeling, and
  client-server architectures.

- Experience in use of commercial expert system shells, preferably Nexpert
  Object, and relational database systems, preferably Oracle.

- Experience with PC/UNIX environments and networking.

- Programming skills in C/C++.

- Strong communication skills - both written and oral.

- Strong commitment, dedication, and motivation to excel.

- Some off-hours (outside of 8 to 5) work may be necessary for software
  installation and testing outside of the customer's normal business hours.

- Some travel between Wisconsin and Pennsylvania.


CONTACT:

Send your resume to:

Mr. Armagan Ozdinc
Unisys Corporation
Valley Forge Engineering Center
Advanced Programs, Bldg. 1
P.O. Box 517
Paoli, PA 19301-0517

Fax:     (610) 648-2288
E-mail:  armagan@vfl.paramax.com (only ASCII version)


         ***** US Permanent Resident status is required *****

Subject: CHICAGO-MOTOROLA AFFIRMATIVE ACTION SPEECH PROCESSING ENGINEER
Date: 12 Apr 1995 22:49:25 GMT
Organization: MCSNet Services

CHICAGO-MOTOROLA AFFIRMATIVE ACTION SPEECH PROCESSING ENGINEER


Our company is a world leader in speech coding technology.  It developed the coding 
algorithms which are employed in digital cellular systems in North America and Japan. 
We are currently working on next generation speech coding algorithms for the 
Pan-European Digital Cellular System, as well as North American Digital Cellular 
systems.  High quality, low data rate speech coding will also be critical for the 
success of the Iddium(TM) system.

In the areas of speech recognition and speech synthesis, our goal is to develop 
robust voice dialog systems which can be embedded into Motorola products.  We are 
currently investigating large vocabulary, speaker independent, continuous speech 
recognition technology.  Particular interest is placed on robustness to harsh 
acoustical conditions (background noise, reverberation, etc.).

Our company is looking for individuals who can contribute to a team environment on 
the development, simulation and implementation of algorithms for state-of the-art 
speech recognition and/or speech coding systems for incorporation into Motorola 
products.

Candidates are required to have knowledge of Digital Signal Processing techniques.  
Course work or experience in speech processing and in particular speech recognition 
or speech coding is highly desirable.  Experience in high level language programming 
is required, preferably C in a UNIX environment.  Expertise in one or more of the 
following areas is also desirable:

Hidden Markov Model (HMM) based speech recognition
Acoustic Phonetic
Statistical Pattern Recognition/Classification
Speech/Source Coding Technology
Artificial Neural Networks
Real-Time Assembly Language Programming
Digital Signal Processor Programming

 Please send resume with compensation history to email psiinc@mcs.com or fax 
708-679-8092.
Attn. Miki. You must use the header to be considered for this position. US RESIDENTS 
ONLY.

To: ai+ai-jobs@CS.CMU.EDU
Subject: Job: Financial Expert Systems at Countrywide Funding, Pasadena, CA
Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU

Countrywide Funding Corp, the nation's largest mortgage lender, is seeking
knowledge engineers for its AI department in Pasadena, California.  Part of the
responsibility will be to enhance and maintain its underwriting expert system,
CLUES, which is described in IAAI '94 and the current issue of AI Magazine. 
CLUES has underwritten over 120,000 mortgage loans and is in daily use in over 
300 branches throughout the country. In addition, the successful candidate will
participate in new projects aimed to apply mature AI technology to diverse 
financial applications. Both junior/medium and senior positions are open.

Candidates should live in the L.A. area (moving expenses are not provided),
have a Masters's degree in computer science or a related field, a couple of
years or more work experience in AI and familiarity with expert system shells
or knowledge induction tools. Good communication skills are essential, since
some of the time is spent with non-technical business people both in knowledge 
acquisition and project planning. Some background in financial applications is
desirable but not required. 

Fax resumes, plus a cover letter describing salary history and phone number, to:

	818 666 5299.

From: AI.Repository@GLINDA.OZ.CS.CMU.EDU
To: ai+ai-jobs@cs.cmu.edu
Subject: Job: Integrating AI with Hypertext (NASA Ames contract position)
Sender: ai@A.GP.CS.CMU.EDU

From: compton@kronos.arc.nasa.gov (Michael Compton)
Subject: Software Engineering at NASA Ames (Mtn. View, CA)
Organization: NASA/ARC Computational Sciences Division
Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 22:56:41 GMT

The following describes a software engineering position at NASA Ames Research
Center in Mountain View, CA.  Note that this is a contractor position, not an
opening for the civil service.  U.S. citizenship or green card required.

Please send resumes to the address at the end of this announcement.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

This individual will support the Advanced Interaction Media group in
integrating Artificial Intelligence technology with state-of-the-art hypertext
and electronic documentation systems.  The person will be responsible for 

  (1) integrating the C++ version of our adaptive technique into the Hyperman
      document viewing system used by flight controllers at JSC mission
      control center; 

  (2) integrating our adaptive technique with the Mosaic World Wide Web
      document viewer; and  

  (3) studying how to apply our adaptive technique to computer-based training 
      applications in the context of intelligent performance support systems;
      and 

  (4) supporting the implementation of new adaptive methods for
      information access.

These tasks require developing an interface between our software and
other existing software, as well as designing new software and user
interface. 

Required skills:
   - MS in Computer Sciences or Electrical Engineering (with major in CS);
   - strong C++ programming skills; good experience with the Unix environment; 
   - knowledge of object oriented design, database and client-server
     programming;  
   - good social and communication skills; 
   - enthusiasm and fast learning skills.

Desirable skills: 
Knowledge of hypertext, information retrieval, multimedia, artificial
intelligence, tutoring systems, computer-based training systems, performance
support systems, intelligent user interfaces, adaptive systems; experience
with the Macintosh environment.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Please send your resume to:

Michael Compton
Computational Sciences Division, M/S 269-2
NASA Ames Research Center
Moffett Field, CA 94035-1000
phone: (415) 604-6776
fax:   (415) 604-3594
internet: compton@ptolemy.arc.nasa.gov

To learn more about Ames's Computational Sciences Division, see:
http://ic-www.arc.nasa.gov/ic/

seeking experienced software engineers with a varying range of
skill-sets.

to fill very soon.  Note that all the positions require 3-5 years of

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 95 15:15:54 -0400
Message-ID: <10994.798232554@GLINDA.OZ.CS.CMU.EDU>
From: Mark Kantrowitz <AI_Repository@GLINDA.OZ.CS.CMU.EDU>
